arch:property.oc:show_val: Frieze Plaque (Probably the Projecting Cover for Wooden Trabes) ? Banquet

div.div:
The scene is divided into two parts and a banquet is depicted on either half of the plaque. A couple, perhaps man and wife, recline on a couch and are attended by two women who stand, facing the couple, one at either end of the couch. A table, laden with dishes and food, is below the couch while a dog, facing the center of the frieze, crouches under the table. The two sections of the frieze are separated by a lebes which rests on its high stand. The plaque is crowned by a cavetto with a molded strigil pattern. Below this, just above the heads of the figure, are rectangular studs, "quincunx". The lower edge of the plaque is decorated by a guilloche. Nail holes pierce the plaque at a slight upward angle. One is between the second and third dish on each table while the others are within the cavetto between the third and fourth strigil at either end.
Moving from left to right: A servant woman stands facing right. Her feet are in profile and the toes of the rear foot nearly touch the heel of the forward foot. She wears a long garment, perhaps a peplos, which falls straight to her ankles; it may have short sleeves which terminate above the elbows. Her right arm hangs at her side and she holds an oinochoe by its highly arched handle in her right hand. Her left elbow is probably pressed to her side and she extends a bowl, held on the palm of her hand, towards the reclining figures on the couch. Her features, just as in all of the figures, are distinctly modeled. Her hair, pulled back behind the ear, falls to her shoulders in three bunches set off by horizontal lines. Her eye is almond-shaped and the nose protrudes over the two rounded lips. Her chin is set back farther than the lips. The next figure reclines right on the couch. He and his companion lie on a cover whose ends fall over both ends of the couch. His shoulders are supported by a small pillow. His knees, covered by a garment, are drawn up and he holds a bowl with a long handle which curves up and in over its bowl. The second reclining figure, probably a woman, turns and looks towards the first; thus, she rests on her right elbow and her torso, including a breast, is visible. She holds a bowl in her left hand. A second serving woman stands at the foot of the couch and extends her left arm towards the second figure. This arm crosses in front of the knees of the latter figure. This serving woman is also clad in a long garment which resembles a peplos. A lebes, resting on a footed stand which is similar to those found in Corinthian pottery, separates this serving woman from her companion who faces the second couch. The latter, clad as the other serving women, does not offer a bowl to the couple but gesticulates with both hands. The reclining figures on the second couch are in the same position as those on the first, except that the second figure, the woman, looks to the right rather than back to her companion. The final serving woman at the far right is the reverse of the first woman. Both couches are elaborately constructed. The rectangular legs at the head rise above the side-boards and are crowned by a small rectangular piece. Two deep concaves, separated by a sharp point, cut into the legs above the circular foot. A three-legged table is under each bed; its feet are difficult to see but seem to be of the usual type: a long slender foot for the front leg, the leg at the left in both tables, and lions" feet for the rear legs. The table top extends beyond the front end of the table. Stretchers, joined to the top of the table by vertical struts, support the legs. Four dishes rest on the table. The first from the left is a low flaring plate and contains four pieces of food; the second and fourth, footed plates, are empty; while the third, a calyx bowl, contains four pieces of food. A narrow-waisted hunting dog crouches under the table. This dog turns towards the center in both scenes. He is smooth-haired and has a narrow tail.
The individual banquet scenes are closely related to similar scenes from later Corinthian or Early Attic Black Figured pottery. Note the similarity between the furniture here and furniture painted by the "C" Painter. This relief seems to represent a transitional stage between line drawing and low relief. Whenever an object or figure passes over a second figure, the artist has cut the front member into the rear member. One may see this on the first serving woman, the second reclining figure (her arm and the left arm of the serving woman), and the fourth reclining figure.
The following parts of the scene are missing in 19660038: the center portion of the cavetto; in the first scene from the left, the areas around the nail holes; in the second scene, torso and head of first serving woman, part of the head of first reclining figure, head and torso of second reclining figure, head and feet of last serving woman.
